publicationStmt.publisher: Thomas Heywood, d. 1641 (1574?-1641) The Fair Maid Of The West. Or, A Girle worth gold. The first part. As it was lately acted before the King and Queen, with approved liking. By the Queens Majesties Comedians. Written by T. H. London Printed for Richard Royston [etc.] 1631

sourceDesc.p:
Play details
The fair maid of the west, part i. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1631. Date first performed: 1597-1604.

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

div2.stage: Enter two Captaines, and Mr. Carrol.

sp.speaker: 1. Capt.
sp.p: When puts my Lord to Sea?

sp.speaker: 2. Capt.
sp.p: When the wind is fair.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
Resolve me I entreat, can you not guess
The purpose of this voyage?

sp.speaker: 1. Capt.
sp.p:
Most men think
The Fleet is bound for the Islands.

sp.speaker: Carr.
sp.p:
Nay, it is like.
The great success at Cales under the conduct
Of such a Noble General, hath put heart
Into the English: They are all on fire
To purchase from the Spaniard. If their Carracks
Come deeply laden, we shall tug with them
For golden spoil.

sp.speaker: 2. Capt.
sp.p: O, were it come to that!

sp.speaker: 1 Capt.
sp.p:
How Plimouth swells with Gallants! how the streets
Glister with gold! You cannot meet a man
But tricked in scarf and feather, that it seems
As if the pride of Englands Gallantry
Were harboured here. It doth appear (methinks)
A very Court of Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Carr.
sp.p:
It doth so.
Where shall we dine today?

sp.speaker: 2. Capt.
sp.p: At the next Tavern by; there is the best wine,

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p:
And the best wench, Besse Bridges, she is the flower
Of Plimouth held: the Castle needs no bush,
Her beauty draws to them more gallant Customers
Than all the signs in the town else.

sp.speaker: 2. Capt.
sp.p:
A sweet Lass,
If I have any judgment.

sp.speaker: 1. Capt.
sp.p:
Now in troth
I think she is honest.

sp.speaker: Carr.
sp.p:
Honest, and live there?
What, in a public Tavern, where is such confluence
Of lusty and brave Gallants? Honest said you?

sp.speaker: 2. Capt.
sp.p: I vow she is for me.

sp.speaker: 1. Capt.
sp.p: For all, I think. I am sure she is wondrous modest.

sp.speaker: Carr.
sp.p:
But withal
Exceeding affable.

sp.speaker: 2 Capt.
sp.p: An argument that she is not proud.

sp.speaker: Carr.
sp.p: No, were she proud, she would fall.

sp.speaker: 1 Capt.
sp.p:
Well, she is a most attractive Adamant,
Her very beauty hath upheld that house,
And gained her master much.

sp.speaker: Carr.
sp.p:
That Adamant
Shall for this time draw me too, we will dine there.

sp.speaker: 2. Capt.
sp.p: No better motion: Come to the Castle then.

div2.stage: Enter M. Spencer, and Capt. Goodlack.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: What, to the old house still?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Canst blame me, Captain,
Believe me, I was never surprised till now,
Or catched upon the sudden.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Pray resolve me,
Why being a Gentleman of fortunes, means,
And well revenued, will you adventure thus
A doubtful voyage, when only such as I
Borne to no other fortunes than my sword
Should seek abroad for pillage.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Pillage, Captain?
No, it is for honour; And the brave society
Of all these shining Gallants that attend
The great Lord. General, drew me hither first:
No hope of gain or spoil.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Aye, but what draws you to this house so oft?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: As if thou knewest it not.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: What, Besse?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Even she.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Come, I must tell you, you forget yourself,
One of your birth and breeding, thus to dote
Upon a Tanners daughter: why, her father
Sold hides in Somersetshire, and being trade-fallen,
Sent her to service.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Prithee speak no more,
Thou tellest me that which I would fain forget,
Or wish I had not known. If thou wilt humour me
Tell me she is fair and honest.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Yes, and loves you.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
To forget that, were to exclude the rest:
All saving that, were nothing. Come let us enter.

sp.speaker: 1. Draw.
sp.p:
You are welcome Gentlemen. Show them into
the next room there.

sp.speaker: 2. Draw.
sp.p:
Look out a Towel, and some Rolls, a Salt and
Trenchers.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: No sir, we will not dine.

sp.speaker: 2. Draw.
sp.p:
I am sure ye would if ye had my stomach.
What wine drink ye, Sack or Claret?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Where is Besse?

sp.speaker: 2. Draw.
sp.p: Marry above with three or four Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Go call her.

sp.speaker: 2. D.
sp.p: I will draw you a cup of the neatest wine in Plimouth

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.p: I will taste none of your drawing. Go call Besse.

sp.speaker: 2. Draw.
sp.p:
There is nothing in the mouths of these Gallants,
but Besse, Besse.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: What say ye Sir?

sp.speaker: 2. Draw.
sp.p: Nothing sir, but I will go call her presently.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Tell her who is here.

sp.speaker: 2. Draw.
sp.p: The devil rid her out of the house for me.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Say ye sir?

sp.speaker: 2 Draw.
sp.p: Nothing but anon anon sir.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: See she is come.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Sweet Master Spencer, you are a stranger grown,
Where have you been these three days?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
The last night
Is ate up late, at game: here take this bag,
And lay it up till I call for it.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Sir I shall.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Bring me some wine.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
I know your taste,
And I shall please your palate.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Troth it is a pretty soul.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
To thee I will unbosom all my thoughts,
Were her low birth but equal with her beauty
Here would I fix my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
You are not mad sir?
You say you love her.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Never question that.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Then put her to it, win Opportunity,
She the best bawd: If (as you say) she loves you,
She can deny you nothing.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
I have proved her
Unto the utmost test. Examined her.
Even to a modest force: but all in vain:
She will laugh, confer, keep company, discourse,
And something more, kiss: but beyond that compass
She no way can be drawn.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
It is a virtue,
But seldom found in taverns.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: It is of the best Graves wine sir.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Gramercy Girl, come sit.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Pray pardon sir, I dare not.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: I will have it so.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
My fellows love me not, and will complain
Of such a saucy boldness.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Pox on your fellows,
I will try whether their pottle pots or heads
Be harder, if I do but hear them grumble.
Sit: now Besse drink to me.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: To your good voyage.

sp.speaker: 2 Draw.
sp.p: Did you call sir?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Yes sir, to have your absence. Captain, this health.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Let it come sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Draw.
sp.p: Must you be set, and we wait, with a -

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: What say you sir?

sp.speaker: 2 Draw.
sp.p: Anon, anon, I come there.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: What will you venture Besse to sea with me?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
What I love best, my heart: for I could wish
I had been borne to equal you in fortune,
Or you so low, to have been ranked with me,
I could have then presumed boldly to say,
I love none but my Spencer.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Besse I thank thee.
Keep still that hundred pound till my return
From the islands with my Lord: if never, wench
Take it, it is thine own.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: You bind me to you.

sp.speaker: 1 Draw.
sp.p:
Besse, you must fill some wine into the Portcullis,
the Gentlemen there will drink none but of your
drawing.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: She shall not rise sir, go let your Master snick-up.

sp.speaker: 1 D.
sp.p: And that should be cousin-german to the hick-up.

sp.speaker: 2 Draw.
sp.p:
Besse, you must needs come, the gentlemen
fling pots, pottles, drawers, and all down stairs. The
whole house is in an uproar.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Pray pardon sir, I needs must be gone.

sp.speaker: 2 D.
sp.p:
The Gentlemen swear if she come not up to them
They will come down to her.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
If they come in peace,
Like civil Gentlemen, they may be welcome:
If otherwise, let them usurp their pleasures.
We stand prepared for both.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
Save you gallants, we are somewhat bold to press
Into your company. It may be held scarce manners,
Therefore fit that we should crave your pardon.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Sir, you are welcome, so are your friends.

sp.speaker: 1 Capt.
sp.p: Some wine.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Pray give me leave to fill it.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
You shall not stir. So please you we will join company.
Drawer, more stools.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I take it that is a she drawer. Are you of the house?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: I am sir.

sp.speaker: Caroll.
sp.p: In what place?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: I draw.

sp.speaker: Caroll.
sp.p: Beer, do you not? You are some tapstress.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Sir, the worst character you can bestow
Upon the maid is to draw wine.

sp.speaker: Caroll.
sp.p:
She would draw none to us,
Perhaps she keeps a Rundlet for your taste,
Which none but you must pierce.

sp.speaker: 2 Capt.
sp.p: I pray be civil.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
I know not, Gentlemen, what your intents be,
Nor do I fear or care. This is my room,
And if you bear you, as you seem in show,
Like Gentlemen, sit and be sociable.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: We will. Minx, by your leave: Remove I say.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: She shall not stir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: How sir?

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.p:
No sir: could you out-face the devil,
We do not fear your roaring.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
Though you may be companion with a drudge,
It is not fit she should have place by us.
About your business, housewife.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
She is worthy
The place as the best here, and she shall keep it.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You lie.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: The Gentleman is slain, away.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: O heaven, what have you done?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Undone thyself and me too: Come away?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
O sad misfortune, I shall lose him ever.
What, are you men or milk sops? Stand you still
Senseless as stones, and see your friend in danger
To expire his last?

sp.speaker: 1 Capt.
sp.p: Tush, all our help is in vain.

sp.speaker: 2 Capt.
sp.p:
This is the fruit of whores.
This mischief came through thee.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: It grew first from your incivility.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p:
Lend me a hand to lift his body hence.
It was a fatal business.

sp.speaker: 1 Dr.
sp.p:
One call my Master, another fetch the constable,
Here is a man killed in the room.

sp.speaker: 2 Dr.
sp.p: How, a man killed sayst thou. Is all paid?

sp.speaker: 1 Dr.
sp.p: How fell they out, canst thou tell?

sp.speaker: 2 Dr.
sp.p:
Sure about this bold Betrice: it is not so much for
the death of the man, but how shall we come by our reckoning?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
What shall become of me! Of all lost creatures
The most infortunate. My innocence
Hath been the cause of blood, and I am now
Purpled with murder, though not within compass
Of the Law's severe censure: but which most
Adds unto my affliction, I by this
Have lost so worthy and approved a friend,
Whom to redeem from exile, I would give
All that is without and in me.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: Your name is Besse Bridges?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
An unfortunate Maid.
Known by that name too well in Plimouth here.
Your business, sir, with me?

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: Know you this Ring?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
I do: it is my Spencers.
I know withal you are his trusty friend,
To whom he would commit it. Speak, how fares he?
Is he in freedom, know ye?

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p:
He is in health
Of body, though in mind somewhat perplexed
For this late mischief happened.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Is he fled, and freed from danger?

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p:
Neither. By this token
He lovingly commends him to you Besse,
And prays you when it is dark meet him on the Hoe
Near to the new-made Fort, where he will attend you,
Before he flies, to take a kind farewell.
There is only Goodlack in his company,
He entreats you not to fail him.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Tell him from me, I will come, I will run, I will fly,
Stand Death before me: were I sure to die.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: You are too full of passion.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Canst thou blame me,
To have the guilt of murder burden me,
And next, my life in hazard to a death
So ignominious: last, to lose a Love
So sweet, so fair, so amorous, and so chaste,
And all these at an instant? Art thou sure
Carol is dead?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
I can believe no less.
You hit him in the very speeding place.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: O but the last of these sits nearest my heart.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Sir be advised by me.
Try her before you trust her. She perchance
May take the advantage of your hopeful fortunes:
But when she finds you subject to distress
And casualty, her flattering love may die:
Your deceased hopes.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Thou counsellest well.
I will put her to the test and utmost trial
Before I trust her further. Here she comes.

div2.stage: Enter Forset, and Besse with a bagge.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: I have done my message sir.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Fear not sweet Spencer, we are now alone,
And thou art sanctuaried in these mine arms.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
While these confer we will sentinel their safety.
This place I will guard.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: I this.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Are you not hurt?
Or your skin razed with his offensive steel?
How is it with you?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Besse, all my afflictions
Are that I must leave thee: thou knowest withal
My extreme necessity, and that the fear
Of a most scandalous death doth force me hence.
I am not near my Country, and to stay
From new supply from thence, might deeply engage me
To desperate hazard.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Is it coin you want?
Here is the hundred pound you gave me late,
Use that, beside what I have stored and saved
Which makes it fifty more: were it ten thousand
Nay, a whole million, Spencer, all were thine.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
No, what thou hast keep still, it is all thine own.
Here be my keys, my trunks take to thy charge:
Such gold fit for transportage as I have,
I will bear along: the rest are freely thine,
Money, apparel, and what else thou findest,
Perhaps worth my bequest and thy receiving,
I make thee mistress of.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Before I doted,
But now you strive to have me ectasied.
What would you have me do, in which to express
My zeal to you?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Which in my chamber hangs,
My picture, I enjoin thee to keep ever,
For when thou partest with that, thou losest me.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
My soul may from my body be divorced,
But never that from me.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
I have a house in Foy, a tavern called
The Windmill, that I freely give thee too,
And thither if I live I will send to thee.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
So soon as I have cast my reckonings up,
And made even with my Master, I will not fail
To visit Foy in Cornwall. Is there else
Aught that you will enjoin me?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Thou art fair,
Join to thy beauty virtue. Many suitors
I know will tempt thee: beauty is a shrewd bait,
But unto that if thou addest chastity,
Thou shalt ore-come all scandal. Time calls hence,
We now must part.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
O that I had the power to make Time lame,
To stay the stars, or make the Moon stand still,
That future day might never haste thy flight.
I could dwell here for ever in thine arms,
And wish it always night.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: We trifle hours. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
First take this Ring:
It was the first token of my constant love
That past betwixt us. When I see this next,
And not my Spencer, I shall think thee dead:
For till death part thy body from thy soul
I know thou wilt not part with it.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Swear for me Besse: for thou mayst safely do it.
Once more farewell: at Foy thou shalt hear from me.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
There is not a word that hath a parting sound
Which through mine ears shrills not immediate death.
I shall not live to lose thee.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: Best be gone, for hark I hear some tread.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
A thousand farewells are in one contracted.
Captain away.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: O, I shall dye.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p:
What mean you Besse, will you betray your friend,
Or call my name in question? Sweet, look up.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Ha, is my Spencer gone?

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p:
With speed towards Foy,
There to take ship for Fiall.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Let me recollect myself,
And what he left in charge. Virtue and Chastity.
Next, with all sudden expedition
Prepare for Foy: all these will I conserve,
And keep them strictly, as I would my life.
Plimouth farewell: in Cornwall I will prove
A second fortune, and for ever mourn,
Until I see my Spencers safe return.

div2.stage: A dumbe Show. Enter Generall, Captaines, the Mayor: Petitioners the other way with papers: amongst these the Drawers. The Generall gives them bagges of money. All goe off saving the two Drawers.

sp.speaker: 1 Draw.
sp.p:
It is well yet we have gotten all the money due
to my Master. It is the commonest thing that can be for
these Captains to score and to score: but when the scores
are to be paid, Non est inventus.

sp.speaker: 2 Draw.
sp.p:
It is ordinary amongst Gallants nowadays,
who had rather swear forty oaths, than only this one
oath, God let me never be trusted.

sp.speaker: 1 Draw.
sp.p:
But if the Captains would follow the noble
mind of the General, before night there would not be
one score owing in Plimouth.

sp.speaker: 2 Draw.
sp.p:
Little knows Besse that my Master hath got
in these desperate debts: but she hath cast up her accounts
and is gone.

sp.speaker: 1 Draw.
sp.p: Whither canst thou tell?

sp.speaker: 2 Draw.
sp.p:
They say to keep a Tavern in Foy, and that
Master. Spencer hath given her a stock to set up for herself.
Well, howsoever, I am glad, though he killed the man we
have got our money.

sp.speaker: Forset.
sp.p: In your time have you seen a sweeter creature?

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: Some week or thereabouts.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p:
And in that small time she hath almost undone
all the other Taverns. The Gallants make no rendezvous
now but at the Wind-mill.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p:
Spite of them I will have her. It shall cost me
the setting on but I will have her.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: Why, do you think she is so easily won?

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p:
Easily or not, I will bid as fair and far as any
man within twenty miles of my head, but I will put her
to the squeak.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p:
They say there are Knight's sons already come
as suitors to her.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p:
It is like enough, some younger brothers, and
so I intend to make them.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p:
If these doings hold, she will grow rich in short
time.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p:
There shall be doings that shall make this
Wind-mill my grand seat, my mansion, my palace, and
my Constantinople.

div2.stage: Enter Besse Bridges like a Mistresse, and Clem.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p:
Here she comes: observe how modestly she bears
herself.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p:
I must know of what burden this vessel is, I
shall not bear with her till she bear with me, and till
then, I cannot report her for a woman of good carriage.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Your old Master that dwelt here before my
coming, hath turned over your years to me.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Right forsooth: before he was a Vintner, he
was a shoo-maker, and left two or three turnovers more
besides myself.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: How long hast thou to serve.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
But eleven years next grass, and then I am in
hope of my freedom. For by that time I shall be at full age.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: How old art thou now?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Forsooth newly come into my Teens. I have
scraped trenchers this two years, and the next Vintage I
hope to be Bar-boy.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: What is thy name?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
My name is Clem, my father was a Baker, and by
the report of his neighbours, as honest a man as ever lived
by bread.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: And where dwelt he?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Below here in the next crooked street, at the
sign of the Leg. He was nothing so tall as I, but a little
wee-man, and somewhat hucked-backed.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: He was once Constable?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
He was indeed, and in that one year of his
reign, I have heard them say, he bolted and sifted out
more business, than others in that office in many years
before him.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: How long is it since he dyed?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Marry the last dear year. For when corn grew
to be at an high rate, my father never dowed after.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: I think I have heard of him.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Then I am sure you have heard he was an honest
neighbour, and one that never loved to be mealy-mouthed.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Well sirrah, prove an honest servant, and you
shall find me your good Mistress. What company is in
the Mermaid?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
There be four Sea captains. I believe they be
little better than spirits, they are so flush of their ruddocks.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
No matter, we will take no note of them.
Here they vent many brave commodities,
By which some gain accrues. They are my good customers,
And still return me profit.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Wot you what Mistress, how the two Sailors
would have served me, that called for the pound and half
of Cheese?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: How was it Clem?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
When I brought them a reckoning, they would
have had me to have scored it up. They took me for a simple
gull indeed, that would have had me to have taken
Chalk for Cheese.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Well, go wait upon the Captains, see them
want no wine.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Nor reckoning neither, take my word Mistress.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p:
She is now at leisure, I will to her.
Lady, what Gentlemen are those above?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Sir they are such as please to be my guests,
And they are kindly welcome.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: Give me their names.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
You may go search the Church-book where
they were christened.
There you perhaps may learn them.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: Minion, how?

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p:
Fie, fie, you are too rude with this fair creature,
That no way seeks to offend you.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Pray hands off.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p:
I tell thee maid, wife, or what ever thou beest,
No man shall enter here but by my leave.
Come, let us be more familiar.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Alas good-man.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p:
Why knowest thou whom thou slightest. I am Roughman,
The only approved gallant of these parts,
A man of whom the Roarers stand in awe,
And must not be put off.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
I never yet heard man so praise himself,
But proved in the end a coward.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p:
Coward, Bess?
You will offend me, raise in me that fury
Your beauty cannot calm. Go to, no more,
Your language is too harsh and peremptory.
Pray let me hear no more of it. I tell thee
That quiet day scarce past me these seven years
I have not cracked a weapon in some fray,
And will I you move my spleen?

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: What, threat a woman?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Sir, if you thus persist to wrong my house,
Disturb my guests, and nightly domineer,
To put my friends from patience, I will complain,
And right myself before the Magistrate.
Can we not live in compass of the Law,
But must be swaggered out of it?

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p:
Go to, wench,
I wish thee well, think on it, there is good for thee
Stored in my breast, and when I come in place
I must have no man to offend mine eye:
My love can brooke no rivals. For this time
I am content your Captains shall have peace,
But must not be used to it.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Sir if you come like other free civil Gentlemen
You are welcome, otherwise my doors are barred you.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p:
That is my good Girl,
I have fortunes laid up for thee: what I have
Command it as thine own. Go to, be wise.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Well, I shall study for it.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: Consider on it. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
My mind suggests me that this prating fellow
Is some notorious Coward. If he persist
I have a trick, to try what mettle is in him.
What news with you?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I am now going to carry the Captains a reckoning.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: And what is the sum?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Let me see, eight shillings and six pence.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: How can you make that good? write them a bill.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
I will watch them for that, it is no time of night to
use our bills, the Gentlemen are no dwarfs, and with one
word of my mouth, I can tell them what is to be-tall.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: How comes it to so much?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Imprimis, six quarts of wine at seven pence the
quart, seven sixpences.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Why dost thou reckon it so?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Because as they came in by hab nab, so I will
bring them in a reckoning at six and at sevens.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Well, wine - three shillings, sixpence

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: And what wants that often groats?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: It is two pence over.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Then put six pence more to it, and make it four shillings,
wine, though you bate it them in their meat.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Why so I prithee?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Because of the old proverb, What they want in
meat, let them take out in drink. Then for twelve pennyworth
of Anchovies, 18 d.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: How can that be?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Marry very well Mistress, 12 d. Anchovies, and
6 d. oil and vinegar. Nay they shall have a saucy reckoning

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: And what for the other half crown?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Bread, beer, salt, napkins, trenchers, one thing
with another, so the summa totalis is - eight shillings, sixpence

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Well, take the reckoning from the bar.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
What needs that forsooth? The Gentlemen seem
to be high-flown already, send them in but another pottle
of Sack, and they will cast up the reckoning of themselves.
Yes, I will about it.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Were I not with so my suitors pestered,
And might I enjoy my Spencer, what a sweet
Contented life were this? For money flows
And my gain is great. But to my Roughman next:
I have a trick to try what spirit is in him,
It shall be my next business: in this passion
For my dear Spencer, I propose me this,
Amongst many sorrows some mirth is not amisse,

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: What were you thinking sir?

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.p:
Troth of the world, what any man should see in it
To be in love with it.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: The reason of your meditation.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
To imagine that in the same instant that one forfeits
all his estate, another enters upon a rich possession: as
one goes to the Church to be married, another is hurried
to the gallows to be hanged, the last having no feeling
of the first man's joy, nor the first of the last man's misery.
At the same time that one lies tortured upon the Rack,
another lies tumbling with his Mistress over head and
ears in down and feathers. This when I truly consider,
I cannot but wonder why any fortune should make a man
ectasied.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: You give yourself too much to melancholy.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
These are my Maxims, and were they as faithfully
practised by others, as truly apprehended by me, we
should have less oppression, and more charity.

div2.stage: Enter the two Captaines that were before.

sp.speaker: 1 Capt.
sp.p: Make good thy words.

sp.speaker: 2 Capt.
sp.p: I say thou hast injured me.

sp.speaker: 1 Capt.
sp.p: Tell me wherein.

sp.speaker: 2 Capt.
sp.p:
When we assaulted Fiall,
And I had by the Generals command
The onset, and with danger of my person
Enforced the Spaniard to a swift retreat,
And beat them from their Fort, thou when thou sawest
All fear and danger past, madest up with me
To share that honour which was sole mine own,
And never ventured shot for it, or ever came
Where bullet grazed.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
See Captain a fray towards,
Let us if we can atone this difference.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Content.

sp.speaker: 1 Capt.
sp.p:
I will prove it with my sword,
That though thou hadst the foremost place in field,
And I the second, yet my Company
Was equal in the entry of the Fort.
My sword was that day drawn as soon as thine,
And that poor honour which I won that day
Was but my merit.

sp.speaker: 2 Capt.
sp.p:
Wrong me palpably
And justify the same?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: You shall not fight.

sp.speaker: 1 Capt.
sp.p:
Why, sir, who made you first a Justicer,
And taught you that word shall? you are no General,
Or if you be, pray show us your Commission.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Sir you have no commission but my counsel,
And that I will show you freely.

sp.speaker: 2 Capt.
sp.p: It is some Chaplain,

sp.speaker: 1 Capt.
sp.p: I do not like his text.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Let us beat their weapons down.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: I will aim at him that offers to divide us?

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p:
Pox of these part-frays, see I am wounded
By beating down my weapon.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: How fares my friend?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
You sought for blood, and Gentlemen you have it,
Let mine appease you, I am hurt to death.

sp.speaker: 1 Capt.
sp.p:
My rage converts to pity, that this Gentleman
Shall suffer for his goodness.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Noble friend,
I will revenge thy death.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.p:
He is no friend
That murmurs such a thought. O Gentlemen.
I killed a man in Plimouth, and by you
Am slain in Fiall. Caroll fell by me,
And I fall by a Spencer. Heaven is just,
And will not suffer murder unrevenged,
Heaven pardon me, as I forgive you both,
Shift for yourselves: away.

sp.speaker: 2 Capt.
sp.p:
We saw him die,
But grieve you should so perish.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.p:
Note Heavens justice,
And henceforth make that use of it. I shall faint.

sp.speaker: 1 Capt.
sp.p:
Short Farewells now must serve. If thou survivest
Live to thine honour: but if thou expirest
Heaven take thy soul to mercy.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
I bleed much,
I must go seek a Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Sir how cheer you?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Like one that is bound upon a new adventure
To the other world: yet thus much worthy friend
Let me entreat you, since I understand
The Fleet is bound for England, take your occasion
To ship yourself, and when you come to Foy
Kindly commend me to my dearest Besse,
Thou shalt receive a Will, in which I have
Possessed her of five hundred pounds a year.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: A noble Legacy.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
The rest I have bestowed amongst my friends,
Only reserving a bare hundred pounds
To see me honestly and well interred.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
I shall perform your trust as carefully
As to my father, breathed he.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Mark me Captain:
Her Legacy I give with this proviso,
If at thy arrival where my Besse remains,
Thou findest her well reported, free from scandal,
My Will stands firm: but if thou hearest her branded
For loose behaviour, or immodest life,
What she should have, I here bestow on thee,
It is thine own: but as thou lovest thy soul
Deal faithfully betwixt my Besse and me.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Else let me dye a prodigy.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
This Ring was hers, that, be she loose or chaste,
Being her own, restore her, she will know it,
And doubtless she deserves it. O my memory,
What had I quite forgot? She hath my picture,

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: And what of that?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
If she be ranked amongst the loose and lewd,
Take it away, I hold it much undecent,
A whore should have it in keeping: but if constant
Let her enjoy it: this my Will perform
As thou art just and honest.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Sense else forsake me.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Now lead me to my Chamber, all is mads even,
My peace with earth, and my atone with heaven.

div2.stage: Enter Besse Bridges like a Page with a sword, and Clem.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
But that I know my mother to be chaste,
I would swear some Soldier got me.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
It may be many a Soldier's Buff Jerkin came
out of your fathers Tan-fat.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Methinks I have a manly spirit in me
In this man's habit.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Now am not I of many men's minds, for if you
should do me wrong, I should not kill you, though I
took you pissing against a wall.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Methinnks I could be valiant on the sudden:
And meet a man in the field.
I could do all that I have heard discoursed
Of Mary Ambree or Westminsters Long-Meg.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
What Mary Ambree was I cannot tell, but unless
you were taller you will come short of Long Meg,

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Of all thy fellows thee I only trust,
And charge thee to be secret.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
I am bound in my Indentures to keep my Masters
secrets, and should I find a man in bed with you, I
would not tell.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Be gone sir, but no words as you esteem my favour.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
But Mistress, I could wish you to look to your
long seams, fights are dangerous. But am not I in a sweet
taking think you?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: I prithee why?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Why, if you should swagger and kill anybody, I
being a Vintner should be called to the Bar.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Let none condemn me of immodesty,
Because I try the courage of a man
Who on my soul is a Coward: beats my servants,
Cuffs them, and as they pass by him kicks my maids,
Nay domineers over me, making himself
Lord over my house and household. Yesternight
I heard him make appointment on some business
To pass alone this way. I will venture fair,
But I will try what is in him.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p:
Sir, I can now no further, weighty business
Calls me away.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p:
Why at your pleasure then,
Yet I could wish that ere I past this field,
That I could meet some Hector, so your eyes
Might witness what myself have oft repeated,
Namely that I am valiant.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: Sir no doubt. But now I am in haste. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Roug.
sp.p:
How many times brave words bear out a man?
For if he can but make a noise, he is feared.
To talk of frays, although he never had heart
To face a man in field, that is a brave fellow,
I have been valiant I must needs confess,
In street and Tavern, where there have been men
Ready to part the fray: but for the fields
They are too cold to fight in.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: You are a villain, a Coward, and you lie.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p:
You wrong me I protest. Sweet courteous Gentleman
I never did you wrong.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Wilt tell me that?
Draw forth thy coward sword, and suddenly,
Or as I am a man I will run thee through,
And leave thee dead in the field.

sp.speaker: Roug.
sp.p:
Hold as you are a Gentleman. I have taken an oath
I will not fight today.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Thou hast took a blow already and the lie,
Will not both these enrage thee?

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p:
No, would you give the bastinado too,
I will not break mine oath.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
O, your name is Roughman.
No day doth pass you but you hurt or kill.
Is this out of your calendar?

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p:
Aye, you are deceived,
I never drew sword in anger I protest,
Unless it were upon some poor weak fellow
That never wore steel about him.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Throw your Sword.

sp.speaker: Roug.
sp.p:
Here sweet young sir, but as you are a gentleman,
Do not impair mine honour.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Tie that shoe.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: I shall sir.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Untruss that point.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: Anything this day to save mine oath.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Enough: yet not enough, lie down
Till I stride over thee.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: Sweet sir anything.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Rise, thou hast leave. Now Roughman thou art blessed
This day thy life is saved, look to the rest.
Take back thy sword.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p:
O you are generous: honour me so much
As let me know to whom I owe my life.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: I am Besse Bridges brother,

sp.speaker: Roug.
sp.p: Still me thought that you were something like her.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
And I have heard,
You domineer and revel in her house,
Control her servants, and abuse her guests,
Which if I ever shall hereafter hear,
Thou art but a dead man.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p:
She never told me of a brother living,
But you have power to sway me.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
But for I see you are a Gentleman,
I am content this once to let you pass,
But if I find you fall into relapse,
The second is far more dangerous.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: I shall fear it. Sir will you take the wine?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
I am for London.
And for these two terms cannot make return:
But if you see my sister, you may say
I was in health.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: Too well, the devil take you.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Pray use her well, and at my coming back
I will ask for your acquaintance. Now farewell.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p:
None saw it: he is gone for London: I am unhurt,
Then who shall publish this disgrace abroad?
One man is no slander, should he speak his worst:
My tongue is as loud as his, but in this country
Both of more fame and credit. Should we contest
I can out-face the proudest. This is then
My comfort: Roughman, thou art still the same,
For a disgrace not seen, is held no shame.

sp.speaker: 1 Sa.
sp.p:
Aboard, aboard, the wind stands fair for England,
The ships have all weighed anchor.

sp.speaker: 2 Sail.
sp.p: A stiff gale blows from the shore.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
The Sailors call aboard, and I am forced
To leave my friend now at the point of death,
And cannot close his eyes. Here is the Will,
Now may I find yon Tanners daughter turned
Unchaste or wanton, I shall gain by it
Five hundred pounds a year: here is good evidence.

sp.speaker: 1 Sailor.
sp.p: Sir will you take the long boat and aboard?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: 3 Sail.
sp.p: What are you ready Mates?

sp.speaker: 1 Sail.
sp.p:
We staid for you. Thou canst not tell who is dead?
The great bell rung out now.

sp.speaker: 3 Sailor.
sp.p:
They say it was for one Spencer, who this night
Died of a mortal wound.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
My worthy friend.
Unhappy man that cannot stay behind
To do him his last rights. Was his name Spencer?

sp.speaker: 3 Sail.
sp.p:
Yes Sir, a Gentleman of good account
And well known in the navy.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
This is the end of all mortality:
It will be news unpleasing to his Besse.
I cannot fair amisse, but long to see
Whether these Lands belong to her or me.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p:
Nay fear not sir, now you have scaped this dressing
My life for yours.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: I thank thee honest Friend.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: Sir I can tell you news.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: What is it I prithee?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p:
There is a Gentleman one of your name,
That died within this hour.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: My name? what was he, of what sickness died he?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p:
No sickness, but a sleight hurt in the body,
Which showed at first no danger, but being searched,
He died at the third dressing.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
At my third search I am in hope of life.
The heavens are merciful.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: Sir doubt not your recovery.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
That hundred pound I had prepared to expend
Upon mine own expected Funeral
I for name sake will now bestow on his.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: A noble resolution.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
What ships are bound for England, I would gladly
Venture to sea, though weak.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: All bound that way are under sail already.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Here is no security,
For when the beaten Spaniards shall return,
They will spoil whom they can find.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p:
We have a ship,
Of which I am Surgeon, that belongs unto
A London merchant, now bound for Mamorah
A town in Barbary, please you to use that,
You shall command free passage: ten months hence
We hope to visit England.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Friend I thank thee.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p:
I will bring you to the Master, who I know
Will entertain you gladly.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.p:
When I have seen the funeral rights performed
To the dead body of my Country man
And kinsman, I will take your courteous offer.
England no doubt will hear news of my death,
How Besse will take it is to me unknown:
On her behaviour I will build my fate,
There raise my love, or thence erect my hate.

sp.speaker: Forset.
sp.p:
O you are well met, just as I prophesied
So it fell out.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: As how I pray?

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p:
Had you but staid the crossing of one field,
You had beheld a Hector, the boldest Trojan
That ever Roughman met with.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: Pray what was he?

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p:
You talk of Little Davy, Cutting Dick,
And divers such, but tush, this hath no fellow.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: Of what stature and years was he?

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p:
Indeed I must confess he was no giant,
Nor above fifty, but he did bestir him,
Was here and there, and every where at once,
That I was never so put to it since the Midwife
First wrapped my head in linen. Let us to Besse.
I will tell her the whole project.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: Here is the house, we will enter if you please.

sp.speaker: Roug.
sp.p:
Where be these Drawers, Rascals I should say?
That will give no attendance.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Anon, anon sir, please you see a room. What you
here again? Now we shall have such roaring.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: You sirrah call your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Yes sir, I know it is my duty to call her Mistress.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: See and the slave will stir.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Yes I do stir.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p:
Shall we have humours, sauce-box, you have ears
I will teach you prick-song.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
But you have now a wrong Sow by the ear. I
will call her,

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: Do sir, you had best.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
If you were twenty Roughmans, if you lug me by
the ears again, I will draw.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: Ha, what will you draw?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
The best wine in the house for your worship: and
I would call her, but I can assure you she is either not stirring,
or else not in case.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: How not in case?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
I think she hath not her smock on, for I think
I saw it lie at her beds head.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: What, Drawers grow capricious?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Help, help.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
What uproar is this? shall we be never rid.
From these disturbances?

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p:
Why how now Besse? Is this your housewifery?
When you are mine I will have you rise as early as the Lark,
Look to the Bar yourself: these lazy rascals
Will bring your state behind hand.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: You lie sir?

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: How? lie?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Yes sir at the Raven in the high-street, I was at
your lodging this morning for a pottle pot.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p:
You will about your business, must you hear
Stand gaping and idle?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
You wrong me sir,
And tyrannize too much over my servants.
I will have no man touch them but myself.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
If I do not put Rats-bane into his wine in stead
of Sugar, say I am no true Baker.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p:
What, rise at noon?
A man may fight a tall fray in a morning,
And one of your best friends to be hacked and mangled,
And almost cut to pieces, and you fast
Close in your bed, never dream of it.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Fought you this day?

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: And never was better put to it in my days.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: I pray, how was it?

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: Thus: as I past yon fields:

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
I pray forsooth, what shall I reckon for the Jowl
of Ling in the Port-cullis.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p:
A pox upon your Jowls, you kitchen stuff,
Go scour your skillets, pots, and dripping-pans,
And interrupt not us.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
The Devil take your Ox-heels, you foul
Cods-head, must you be kicking?

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: Minion dare you scold?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Yes sir, and lay my ladle over your coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
I do not think that thou darest strike a man,
That swaggerest thus over women.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: How now Besse?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Shall we be never quiet?

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: You are too rude.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: Now I profess all patience.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Then proceed.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p:
Rising up early, Minion whilst you slept,
To cross yon field, I had but newly parted
With this my friend, but that I soon espied
A gallant fellow, and most strongly armed.
In the mid-field we met, and both being resolute,
We jostled for the wall.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Why, did there stand a wall in the mid-field?

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p:
I meant strove for the way.
Two such brave spirits meeting, straight both drew.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
The Maid forsooth sent me to know whether
you would have the shoulder of mutton roasted or sod.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: A mischief on your shoulders.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: That is the way to make me never prove good porter

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: You still heap wrongs on wrongs.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p:
I was in fury
To think upon the violence of that fight,
And could not stay my rage.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: Once more proceed.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p:
O had you seen two tilting meteors jostle
In the mid Region, with like fear and fury
We two encountered. Not Briarius
Could with his hundred hands have struck more thick.
Blows came about my head, I took them still.
Thrusts by my sides betwixt body and my arms,
Yet still I put them by.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
When they were past he put them by. Go on.
But in this fury what became of him?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p:
I think I paid him home, he is soundly mauled,
I bosomed him at every second thrust.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Scaped he with life?

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p:
Aye, that is my fear: if he recover this,
I will never trust my sword more.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Why fly you not if he be in such danger?

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p:
Because a witch once told me
I never should dye for murder.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
I believe thee,
But tell me pray, was not this gallant fellow,
A pretty fair young youth about my years?

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: Even thereabout.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: He was not fiftie then.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Much of my stature?

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: Much about your pitch,

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: He was no giant then.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: And wore a suit like this?

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: I half suspect.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
That gallant fellow,
So wounded and so mangled, was myself,
You base white-livered slave, it was this shoe
That thou stooped to untie: untrussed those points:
And like a beastly coward lay along,
Till I strid over thee. Speak, was it not so?

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: It cannot be denied.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Hare-hearted fellow, Milk-sop, dost not blush?
Give me that Rapier: I will make thee swear,
Thou shalt redeem this scorn thou hast incurred,
Or in this woman shape I will cudgel thee,
And beat thee through the streets. As I am Besse, I will do it.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: Hold, hold; I swear.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Dare not to enter at my door till then.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: Shame confounds me quite.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
That shame redeem: perhaps we will do thee grace
I love the valiant, but despise the base.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Will you be kicked sir?

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p:
She hath wakened me,
And kindled that dead fire of courage in me,
Which all this while hath slept: To spare my flesh
And wound my fame, what is it? I will not rest
Till by some valiant deed I have made good
All my disgraces past. I will cross the street,
And strike the next brave fellow that I meet.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: I am bound to see the end of it.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: Are you sir?

div2.stage: Enter Mayor of Foy, an Alderman, and Servant.

sp.speaker: Mayor.
sp.p:
Believe me sir, she bears herself so well,
No man can justly blame her: and I wonder
Being a single woman as she is,
And living in an house of such resort,
She is no more distasted.

sp.speaker: Alder.
sp.p:
The best Gentlemen
The Country yields, become her daily guests.
Sure sir I think she is rich.

sp.speaker: Mayor.
sp.p:
Thus much I know, would I could buy her state
Were it for a brace of thousands.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p:
It was said a ship is now put into harbour,
Know whence she is.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I will bring news from the key.

sp.speaker: Mayor.
sp.p:
To tell you true sir, I could wish a match
Betwixt her and mine own and only son,
And stretch my purse too upon that condition.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Please you I will motion it.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p:
One of the ships is new come from the Islands,
The greatest man of note is one Captain Goodlack.
It is but a small Vessel.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
I will meet you straight at the Windmill.
Not one word of my name.

sp.speaker: 1 Sail.
sp.p: We understand you.

sp.speaker: Mayor.
sp.p: Sir it is told us you came late from the Islands!

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: I did so:

sp.speaker: Mayor.
sp.p: Pray sir the news from thence.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
The best is, that the General is in health,
And Fiall won from the Spaniards: but the Fleet
By reason of so many dangerous tempests
Extremely weather beaten. You sir I take it,
Are Mayor of the town.

sp.speaker: Mayor.
sp.p: I am the Kings Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
I have some Letters of import from one
A Gentleman of very good account,
That died late in the Islands, to a Maid
That keeps a Tavern here.

sp.speaker: Mayor.
sp.p: Her name Besse Bridges?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
The same. I was desired to make inquiry
What fame she bears, and what report she is of.
Now you sir being here chief Magistrate,
Can best resolve me.

sp.speaker: Mayor.
sp.p:
To our understanding,
She is without stain or blemish well reputed,
And by her modesty and fair demeanour,
Hath won the love of all.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: The worse for me.

sp.speaker: Alder.
sp.p:
I can assure you many narrow eyes
Have looked on her and her condition,
But those that with most envy have endeavoured
To entrap her, have returned won by her virtues.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
So all that I inquire of make report.
I am glad to hear it. Sir I have now some business,
And I of force must leave you.

sp.speaker: Mayor.
sp.p: I entreat you to sup with me tonight.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Sir I may trouble you.
Five hundred pound a year out of my way.
Is there no flaw that I can tax her with,
To forfeit this revenue? Is she such a Saint,
None can mis-say her? why then I myself
Will undertake it. If in her demeanour
I can but find one blemish, stain or spot,
It is five hundred pound a year well got.

div2.stage: Enter Clem and the Sailors on the one side, at the other Roughman, who drawes upon them, and beates them off.
Enter Besse, Clem, and the Sailors.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: But did he fight it bravely?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
I assure you mistress most dissolutely: he hath
run this Sailor three times through the body, and yet
never touched his skin.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: How can that be?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Through the body of his doublet I meant.

sp.speaker: Besse,
sp.p:
How shame, base imputation, and disgrace
Can make a coward valiant: Sirrah you
Look to the bar.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I will hold up my hand there presently.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: I understand, you came now from the Islands,

sp.speaker: 1 Sail.
sp.p: We did so.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
If you can tell me tidings of one Gentleman
I shall require you largely.

sp.speaker: 1 Sailor.
sp.p: Of what name?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: One Spencer.

sp.speaker: 1 Sailor.
sp.p: We both saw and knew the man.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Only for that call for what wine you please.
Pray tell me where you left him.

sp.speaker: 2 Sailor.
sp.p: In Fiall.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Was he in health? how did he fare?

sp.speaker: 2 Sail.
sp.p: Why well.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
For that good news, spend, revel, and carouse,
Your reckoning is paid before-hand. I am ectasied,
And my delights unbounded.

sp.speaker: 1 Sail.
sp.p: Did you love him?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Next to my hopes in heaven.

sp.speaker: 1 Sail.
sp.p: Then change your mirth.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Why, as I take it, you told me he was well,
And shall I not rejoice?

sp.speaker: 1 Sail.
sp.p: He is well in heaven, For Mistress, he is dead,

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Ha, dead! was it so you said? Thou hast given me, friend
But one wound yet, speak but that word again,
And kill me out-right.

sp.speaker: 2 Sail.
sp.p: He lives not.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
And shall I? Wilt thou not break heart?
Are these my ribs wrought out of brass or steel,
Thou canst not craze their bars?

sp.speaker: 1 Sail.
sp.p: Mistress use patience, which conquers all despair.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
You advise well:
I did but jest with sorrow: you may see
I am now in gentle temper.

sp.speaker: 2 Sail.
sp.p: True, we see it.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Pray take the best room in the house, and there
Call for what wine best tastes you: at my leisure
I will visit you myself.

sp.speaker: 1 Sail.
sp.p: I will use your kindness.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
That it should be my fate. Poor poor sweetheart
I do but think how thou becomest thy grave,
In which would I lay by thee: what is my wealth
To enjoy it without my Spencer. I will now
Study to die, that I may live with him.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
The further I inquire, the more I hear
To my discomfort. If my discontinuance
And change at Sea disguise me from her knowledge
I shall have scope enough to prove her fully.
This sadness argues she hath heard some news
Of my Friends death.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
It cannot sure be true
That he is dead, Death could not be so envious
To snatch him in his prime. I study to forget
That ever was such a man.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
If not impeach her,
My purpose is to seek to marry her.
If she deny me, I will conceal the Will,
Or at the least make her compound for half.
Save you fair Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: You are welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
I hear say there is a whore here that draws wine,
I am sharp set, and newly come from sea,
And I would see the trash.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Sure you mistake sir.
If you desire attendance and some wine
I can command you both. Where be these boys?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Are you the Mistress?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: I command the house.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Of what birth are you, pray?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: A Tanners daughter.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Where borne?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: In Somersetshire.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
A trade-fallen Tanners daughter go so brave:
O you have tricks to compass these gay clothes.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: None sir, but what are honest.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: What is your name?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Besse Bridges most men call me.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: You are a whore.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Sir, I will fetch you wine to wash your mouth,
It is so foul, I fear it may fester else.
There may be danger in it.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Not all this move her patience.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Good sir, at this time I am scarce myself
By reason of a great and weighty loss
That troubles me: but I should know that Ring.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
How, this, you baggage? It was never made
To grace a strumpets finger.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Pardon sir, I both must and will leave you.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Did not this well? This will stick in my stomach
I could repent my wrongs done to this maid:
But I will not leave her thus: if she still love him,
I will break her heart-strings with some false report
Of his unkindness.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
You are welcome Gentleman: what wine will
you drink? Claret, Metheglin, or Muscadine, Cider or
Perry, to make you merry, Aragoosa, or Peter-see-mee,
Canary or Charnico? But by your nose sir you should love
a cup of Malmsey: you shall have a cup of the best in Cornwaile.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Here is a brave drawer will quarrel with his wine.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
But if you prefer the Frenchman before the
Spaniard, you shall have either here of the deep red grape
or the pallid white. You are a pretty tall Gentleman, you
should love High-Country wine: none but Clerks and
Sextons love Graves wine. Or are you a married man, I will
furnish you with bastard, white or brown, according to
the complexion of your bed-fellow.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
You rogue, how many years of your prenticeship
Have you spent in studying this set speech?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
The first line of my part was, Anon anon, sir: and
the first question I answered to, was logger-head, or blockhead,
I know not whether.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Speak, where is your Mistress?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Gone up to her chamber.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Set a pottle of Sack in the fire, and carry it into
the next room.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Score a pottle of Sack in the Crown, and see at
the bar for some rotten eggs to burn it: we must have
one trick or other to vent away our bad commodities.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
To dye, and not vouchsafe some few commends
Before his death, was most unkindly done.
This Picture is more courteous: it will not shrink
For twenty thousand kisses: no nor blush:
Then thou shalt be my husband, and I vow
Never to marry other.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Where is this harlot?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
You are immodest sir to press thus rudely
Into my private chamber.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Pox of modesty
When punks must have it mincing in their mouths.
And have I found thee? then shalt hence with me.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Rob me not of the chiefest wealth I have:
Search all my trunks, take the best Jewels there:
Deprive me not that treasure, I will redeem it
With plate, and all the little coin I have,
So I make keep that still.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Thinkst thou that bribes
Can make me leave my friends Will unperformed?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: What was that Friend?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
One Spencer, dead in the Islands,
Whose very last words uttered at his death
Were these, If ever thou shalt come to Foy,
Take thence my picture, and deface it quite:
For let it not be said, my portraiture
Shall grace a strumpets chamber.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
It was not so:
You lie, you are a villain: it was not so.
It is more than sin thus to belie the dead:
He knew if ever I would have transgressed,
It had been with him: he durst have sworn me chaste,
And died in that belief.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p:
Are you so brief?
Nay, I will not trouble you: God be with you.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Yet leave me still that Picture, and I will swear
You are a Gentleman, and cannot lie.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: I am inexorable.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Are you a Christian, have you any name
That ever good man gave you?
It was no Saint you were called after. What is thy name?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: My name is Captain Thomas Good -

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
I can see no good in thee, Race that syllable
Out of thy name.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Goodlack is my name.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
I cry you mercy sir: I now remember you,
You were my Spencers friend, and I am sorry,
Because he loved you, I have been so harsh:
For whose sake, I entreat ere you take it hence,
I may but take my leave of it.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: You will return it?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: As I am chaste I will.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: For once I will trust you.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
O thou the perfect semblance of my Love,
And all that is left of him, take one sweet kiss,
As my last farewell. Thou resemblest him
For whose sweet safety I was every morning
Down on my knees, and with the Lark's sweet tunes
I did begin my prayers: and when sad sleep
Had charmed all eyes, when none save the bright stars
Were up and waking, I remembered thee,
But all, all to no purpose.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Sure, most sure, this cannot be dissembled.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
To thee I have been constant in thine absence,
And when I looked upon this painted piece
Remembered thy last rules and principles:
For thee I have given alms, visited prisons,
To Gentlemen and passengers lent coin,
That if they ever had ability
They might repay it to Spencer: yet for this,
All this, and more, I cannot have so much
As this poor table.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I should question truth, if I should wrong this creature.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
I am resolved.
See sir, this Picture I restore you back,
Which since it was his will you should take hence,
I will not wrong the dead.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: God be with you.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
One word more.
Spencer you say was so unkind in death.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: I tell you true.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
I do entreat you even for goodness sake
Since you were one that he entirely loved,
If you some few days hence hear me expired,
You will amongst other good men, and poor people
That haply may miss Besse, grace me so much
As follow me to the grave. This if you promise,
You shall not be the least of all my friends
Remembered in my will. Now fare you well.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Had I a heart of flint or adamant
It would relent at this. My Mistress Besse,
I have better tidings for you.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: You will restore my Picture? will you?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Yes, and more than that,
This Ring from my friends finger sent to you,
With infinite commends.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: You change my blood.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
These writings are the evidence of Lands,
Five hundred pound a year is bequeathed to you,
Of which I here possess you: all is yours.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
This surplusage of love, hath made my loss
That was but great before: now infinite.
It may be compassed: there is in this my purpose
No impossibility.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: What study you?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Four thousand pound besides this Legacy,
In Jewels, gold, and silver I can make,
And every man discharged. I am resolved
To be a pattern to all Maids hereafter
Of constancy in love.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p:
Sweet Mistress Besse, will you command my service,
Is to succeed your Spencer in his Love,
I would expose me wholly to your wishes.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Alas my love sleeps with him in his grave,
And cannot thence be wakened: yet for his sake
I will impart a secret to your trust,
Which, saving you, no mortal should partake.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Both for his love and yours, command my service.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
There is a prise
Brought into Famouth Road, a good tight Vessel,
The Bottom will but cost eight hundred pound,
You shall have money: buy it.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: To what end?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
That you shall know hereafter. Furnish her
With all provision needful: spare no cost:
And join with you a ging of lusty lads,
Such as will bravely man her: all the charge
I will commit to you: and when she is fitted,
Captain she is thine own.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: I sound it not.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Spare me the rest. This voyage I intend,
Though some may blame, all Lovers will commend.

div2.stage: After an Alarmne, Enter a Spanish Captaine, with Saylors, bringing in a Merchant, Spencer, and the Surgion prisoners.

sp.speaker: Spaniard.
sp.p:
For Fialls loss, and spoil by the English done,
We are in part revenged. There is not a Vessel
That bear upon her top Saint. Georges Cross,
But for that act shall suffer.

sp.speaker: Merchant.
sp.p:
Insult not Spaniard,
Nor be too proud, that thou by odds of Ships,
Provision, men, and powder madest us yield.
Had you come one to one, or made assault
With reasonable advantage, we by this
Had made the carcass of your ship your graves,
Low sunk to the Seas bottom.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p:
Englishman, thy ship shall yield us pillage,
These prisoners we will keep in strongest Hold,
To pay no other ransom than their lives.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Degenerate Spaniard, there is no nobleness in thee
To threaten men unarmed and miserable,
Thou mightst as well tread over a field of slaughter,
And kill them over, that are already slain,
And brag thy manhood.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: Sirrah, what are you?

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.p:
Thy equal as I am a prisoner,
But once to stay a better man than thou,
A Gentleman in my Country.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p:
Wert thou not so, we have strappados, bolts,
And engines to the Main-mast-fastened,
Can make you gentle.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Spaniard do thy worst, thou canst not act
More tortures than my courage is able to endure.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p:
These Englishmen
Nothing can daunt them; Even in misery
They will not regard their masters.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Masters! Insulting bragging Thrasoes.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p:
His sauciness we will punish above the rest.
About their censures we will next devise,
And now towards Spain with our brave English prise.

div2.stage: Enter Besse, Mayor, Alderman, Clem. A table set out, and stooles.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: A Table and some stools.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: I shall give you occasion to ease your tails presently.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Will it please you sit?

sp.speaker: Mayor.
sp.p: With all our hearts, and thank you.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Fetch me that parchment in my Closet window.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: The three sheep-skins with the wrong side outward

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: That with the seal.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
I hope it is my Indenture, and now she means
to give me my time.

sp.speaker: Alder.
sp.p:
And now you are alone, fair Mistress Elzabeth
I think it good to taste you with a motion.
That no way can displease you.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Pray speak on.

sp.speaker: Alder.
sp.p:
It hath pleased here Master Mayor so far to look
Into your fair demeanour, that he thinks you
A fit match for his Son.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Here is the parchment, but if it be the lease of
your house, I can assure you it is out.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: The years are not expired.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: No, but it is out of your Closet.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: About your business.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: Here is even Susanna betwixt the two wicked elders.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: What think you Mistress Elzabeth?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Sir I thank you.
And how much I esteem this goodness from you
The trust I shall commit unto your charge
Will truly witness. Marry, gentle Sir!
Alas I have sadder business now in hand,
Than sprightly marriage, witness these my tears.
Pray read there.

sp.speaker: Maior.
sp.p:
The last Will and Testament of Elzabeth Bridges
to be committed to the trust of the Mayor and Aldermen
of Foy, and their Successors for ever.
To set up young beginners in their trade, a thousand pound
To relieve such as have had loss by Sea, 500 pound.
To every Maid that is married out of Foy,
Whose name is Elzabeth ten pound.
To relieve maimed Soldiers, by the year ten pound.
To Captain Goodlacke, if he shall perform
The business he is employed in, five hundred pound.
The Legacies for Spencer thus to stand,
To number all the poorest of his kin,
And to bestow on them. Item to -

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Enough: you see sir I am now too poor
To bring a dowry with me fit for your son.

sp.speaker: Mayor.
sp.p:
You want a president, you so abound
In charity and goodness.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
All my servants
I leave at your discretions to dispose
Not one but I have left some Legacy.
What shall become of me, or what I purpose
Spare further to enquire.

sp.speaker: Mayor.
sp.p:
We will take our leaves.
And prove to you faithful Executors.
In this bequest.

sp.speaker: Alder.
sp.p:
Let never such despair,
As dying rich, shall make the poor their heir.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Why what is all the wealth the world contains,
Without my Spencer?

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p:
Where is my sweet Besse?
Shall I become a welcome suitor now?
That I have changed my Copy?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
I joy to hear it.
I will find employment for you.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
A gallant ship, and wondrous proudly trimmed,
Well caulked, well tackled, every way prepared.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Here then our mourning for a season end.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p:
Besse, shall strike that Captain? say the word,
I will have him by the ears.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Not for the world.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: What saith that fellow?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: He desires your love, good Captain let him have it.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Then change a hand.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Resolve me all. I am bound upon a voyage,
Will you in this adventure take such part,
As I myself shall do?

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: With my fair Besse, to the worlds end.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Then Captain and Lieutenant both, join hands,
Such are your places now.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: We two are friends.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
I next must swear you two, with all your ging
True to some articles you must observe,
Reserving to myself a prime command,
Whilst I enjoin nothing unreasonable.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: All this is granted.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Then first, you said your ship was trim and gay,
I will have her pitched all over, no spot of white,
No colour to be seen, no Sail but black,
No Flag but sable.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: It will be ominous, and bode disaster fortune.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: I will have it so.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Why then she shall be pitched black as the devil,

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
She shall be called The Negro, when you know
My conceit, Captain, you will thank for it.

sp.speaker: Roug.
sp.p: But whither are we bound?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Pardon me that.
When we are out at sea I will tell you all.
For mine own wearing I have rich apparel,
For man or woman as occasion serves.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
But Mistress, if you be going to sea, what shall
become of me aland.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: I will give thee thy full time.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
And shall I take time, when time is, and let my
Mistress slip away. No, it shall be seen that my teeth are
as strong to grind biscuit as the best sailor of them all, and
my stomach as able to digest powdered beef and Poor-john.
Shall I stay here to score a pudding in the Half moon,
and see my Mistress at the Main yard with her
sails up, and spread. No it shall be seen that I who have
been brought up to draw wine, will see what water the
ship draws, or I will bewray the Voyage.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
If thou hast so much courage, the Captain shall
accept thee.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
If I have so much courage? When did you see
a black beard with a white liver, or a little fellow without
a tall stomach. I doubt not but to prove an honour
to all the Drawers in Cornwall.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: What now remains?

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: To make myself associate in this bold enterprise.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Most gladly sir.
And now our number is full, what is to be done.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
First, at my charge I will feast the town of Foy,
Then set the Cellars ope, that these my Mates
May quaff unto the health of our boon voyage,
Our needful things being once conveyed aboard,
Then casting up our caps in sign of joy,
Our purpose is to bid farewell to Foy.

div2.stage: Enter Mullisheg. Bashaw Alcade, and Ioffer: with other Attendants.

sp.speaker: Mullish.
sp.p:
Out of these bloody and intestine broils
We have at length attained a fortunate peace,
And now at last established in the Throne
Of our great Ancestors, and reign King
Of Fosse and great Morocco.

sp.speaker: Alcade.
sp.p:
Mighty Mullisheg,
Pride of our age, and glory of the Moors,
By whose victorious hand all Barbary
Is conquered, awed, and swayed: behold thy vassals
With loud applauses greet thy victory.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Upon the slaughtered bodies of our foes,
We mount our high Tribunal, and being sole
Without competitor, we now have leisure
To stablish laws first for our Kingdoms safety,
The enriching of our public Treasury,
And last our state and pleasure: then give order
That all such Christian Merchants as have traffic
And freedom in our Country, that conceal
The least part of our Custom due to us,
Shall forfeit ship and goods.

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p:
There are appointed
Unto that purpose careful officers.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Those forfeitures must help to furnish up
The exhausted treasure that our wars consumed,
Part of such profits as accrue that way
We have already tasted.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p:
It is most fit,
Those Christians that reap profit: by our Land
Should contribute unto so great a loss.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Alcade, They shall. But what is the style of King
Without his pleasure? Find us concubines,
The fairest Christian Damsels you can hire,
Or buy for gold: the loveliest of the Moors
We can command, and Negroes every where:
Italians, French, and Dutch, choice Turkish Girls
Must fill our Alkedavy, the great Palace,
Where Mullisheg now deigns to keep his Court.

sp.speaker: Ioffer.
sp.p:
Who else are worthy to be Libertines,
But such as bear the Sword?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Ioffer, Thou pleasest us.
If Kings on earth be termed Demigods,
Why should we not make here terrestrial heaven?
We can, we will, our God shall be our pleasure,
For so our Mecan Prophet warrants us.
And now the music of the Drums surcease,
We will learn to dance to the soft tunes of peace.

div2.stage: Enter Besse like a Sea-captaine, Goodlacke, Roughman, Forset, and Clem.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Good morrow Captain. O this last Sea-fight
Was gallantly performed. It did me good
To see the Spanish Caravel veil her top
Unto my Maiden Flag. Where ride we now?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Among the Islands.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: What coast is this we now descry from far.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Yon Fort is called Fiall.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Is that the place where Spencers body lies?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Yes, in yon Church he is buried.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Then know, to this place was my voyage bound
To fetch the body of my Spencer thence.
In his own Country to erect a tomb,
And lasting monument, where when I die
In the same bed of earth my bones may lie.
Then all that love me, arm and make for shore,
Yours be the spoil, be mine, I crave no more.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p:
May that man dye derided and accursed
That will not follow where a woman leads.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Roughman, you are too rash, and counsel ill,
Have not the Spaniards fortified the town?
In all our Ging we are but sixty five.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: Come, I will make one.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Attend me good Lieutenant,
And sweet Besse, listen what I have devised,
With ten tall Fellows I have manned our Boat,
To see what straggling Spaniards they can take.
And see where Forset is returned with prisoners.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p:
These Spaniards we by break of day surprised,
As they were ready to take boat for Fishing.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Spaniards, upon your lives resolve us truly
How strong is the Town and Fort.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p:
Since English Rawleigh wan and spoiled it first,
The Town is re-edified, and Fort new built,
And four Field-pieces in the Block-house lie
To keep the Harbours mouth.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: And what is one ship to these?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Was there not in the time of their abode
A Gentleman called Spencer buried there
Within the Church, whom some report was slain,
Or perished by a wound?

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p:
Indeed there was,
And over him raised a goodly monument,
But when the English Navy were sailed thence,
And that the Spaniards did possess the Town,
Because they held him for an Heretic,
They straight removed his body from the Church.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
And would the tyrants be so uncharitable
To wrong the dead? where did they then bestow him?

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: They buried him in the fields.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: O still more cruel.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p:
The man that ought the field, doubtful his corn
Would never prosper whilst an heretics body
Lay there, he made petition to the Church
To have it digged up and burnt, and so it was.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
What is he that loves me would persuade me live,
Not rather leap over hatches into the Sea:
Yet ere I die I hope to be revenged
Upon some Spaniards for my Spencers wrong.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: Let us first begin with these.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Alas these poor slaves! besides their pardoned lives
One give them money. And Spaniards where you come,
Pray for Besse Bridges, and speak well of the English.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: We shall.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Our mourning we will turn into revenge,
And since the Church hath censured so my Spencer,
Bestow upon the Church some few cast Pieces,
Command the Gunner do it.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: And if he can to batter it to the earth.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: A Sail, a Sail.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: From whence?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
A pox upon yon Gunner, could he not give warning
before he had shot?

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: Why I prithee?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Why? I was sent to the top-mast to watch, and
there I fell fast asleep. Bounce quoth the guns, down
tumbles Clem, and if by chance my feet had not hung in
the tackles, you must have sent to England for a bone-setter,
for my neck had been in a pitiful taking,

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: Thou toldest us of a Sail.

sp.speaker: Sailor.
sp.p:
Arm Gentlemen, a gallant ship of war
Makes with her full sails this way: who it seems
Hath took a Bark of England.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Which we will rescue.
Or perish in the adventure. You have sworn
That howsoever we conquer or miscarry
Not to reveal my sex.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We have.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Then for your Countries honour, my revenge,
For your own fame, and hope of golden spoil,
Stand bravely to it. The manage of the fight
We leave to you.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p:
Then now up with your fights, let your ensigns
Blessed with Saint. Georges Cross, play with the winds.
Fair Besse, keep you your cabin.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Captain you wrong me, I will face the fight,
And where the bullets sing loudest about mine ears,
There shall you find me cheering up my men.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: This wench would of a coward make an Hercules.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Trumpets a charge, and with your whistles shrill
Sound boatswains an alarum to your mates.
