With music cheer up their astonished souls,
The whilst the thundering Ordnance bear the Base.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
To fight against the Spaniards we desire,
Alarm Trumpets.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: Gunners straight give fire.

div2.stage: Enter Goodlacke hurt. Besse, Roughman, Forset, Clem.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
I am shot and can no longer man the Deck,
Yet let not my wound daunt your courage mates.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
For every drop of blood that thou hast shed,
I will have a Spaniards life. Advance your Targets,
And now cry all, Board, board, amain for England.

div2.stage: Enter with victory Besse, Roughman, Forset, Clem, &c. The Spaniards Prisoners.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: How is it with the Captain?

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p:
Nothing dangerous,
But being shot in the thigh he keeps his Cabin,
And cannot rise to greet your victory.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: He stood it bravely out whilst he could stand.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
But for these Spaniards, now you Don Diegoes,
You that made Paules to stink.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p:
Before we further censure them, let us know
What English prisoners they have here aboard.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p:
You may command them all. We that were now
Lords over them, Fortune hath made your slaves,
Release our prisoners.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Had my captain died
Not one proud Spaniard had escaped with life,
Your ship is forfeit to us, and your goods.
So live. Give him his long Boat: him and his
Set safe ashore; and pray for English Besse.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
I know not whom you mean, but be it your Queen
Famous Elizabeth, I shall report
She and her subjects both are merciful.

div2.stage: Enter Roughman, with the Merchant and Spencer.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Whence are you sir? and whither were you bound?

sp.speaker: Merch.
sp.p:
I am a London bound for Barbary,
But by this Spanish Man-of-war surprised,
Pillaged and captived.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
We much pity you,
What loss you have sustained, this Spanish prey
Shall make good to you to the utmost farthing.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p:
Our lives, and all our fortunes whatsoever
Are wholly at your service.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
These Gentlemen have been dejected long,
Let me peruse them all, and give them money
To drink our health, and pray forget not Sirs,
To pray for - Hold, support me, or I faint.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p:
What sudden unexpected ecstasy
Disturbs your conquest.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Interrupt me not,
But give me way for Heavens sake.

sp.speaker: Spencer.
sp.p:
I have seen a face ere now like that young Gentleman,
But not remember where.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
But he was slain,
Lay buried in yon Church, and thence removed,
Denied all Christian rights, and like an Infidel
Confined unto the fields, and thence digged up,
His body after death had martyrdom:
All these assure me it is his shadow dogs me,
For some most just revenge thus far to Sea.
Is it because the Spaniards scaped with life,
That were to thee so cruel after death
Thou hauntest me thus? Sweet ghost thy rage forbear,
I will revenge thee on the next we seize.
I am amazed, this sight I will not endure.
Sleep, sleep, fair ghost, for thy revenge is sure.

sp.speaker: Roug.
sp.p: Forset, convey the owner to his cabin.

sp.speaker: Spencer.
sp.p: I pray sir what young Gentleman is that?

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p:
He is both the owner of the ship and goods,
That for some reasons hath his name concealed.

sp.speaker: Spencer.
sp.p:
Methinks he looks like Besse, for in his eyes
Lives the first love that did my heart surprise.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p:
Come Gentlemen, first make your losses good
Out of this Spanish prize. Let us then divide
Both several ways, and heavens be our guide.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: We towards Mamorrah.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p:
We where the Fates do please,
Till we have tract a wilderness of Seas.
Our Stage so lamely can express a Sea,
That we are forced by Chorus to discourse
What should have been in action. Now imagine
Her passion over, and Goodlacke well recovered,
Who had he not been wounded and seen Spencer,
Had sure descried him. Much prise they have ta'en,
The French and Dutch she spares, only makes spoil
Of the rich Spaniard, and the barbarous Turk.
And now her fame grows great in all these seas.
Suppose her rich, and forced for want of water
To put into Mamorrah in Barbary,
Where wearied with the habit of a man,
She was discovered by the Moors aboard,
Which told it to the amorous King of Fesse,
That never before had English Lady seen.
He sends for her on shore, how he receives her,
How she and Spencer meet, must next succeed.
Sit patient then, when these are fully told,
Some may hap say, I, there is a Girl worth gold.

div2.stage: Enter Mullisheg, Alcade, Ioffer, and Attendants, &c.

sp.speaker: Mullisheg.
sp.p: But was she of such presence?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: To describe her were to make eloquence dumb

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Well habited?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: I never beheld a beauty more complete.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Thou hast inflamed our spirits. In England borne?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: The Captain so reported.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: How her ship?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p:
I never saw a braver Vessel sail,
And she is called The Negro.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Ominous
Perhaps to our good fate, She in a Negro
Hath sailed thus far to bosom with a Moore.
But for the motion made to come ashore,
How did she relish that?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p:
I promised to the Captain large reward
To win him to it, and this day he hath promised
To bring me her free answer.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
When he comes
Give him the entertainment of a Prince.
The news with thee?

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.p:
The Captain of The Negro craves admittance
Unto your Highness presence.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p:
A Guard attend him, and our noblest Bashawes
Conduct him safe where we will parley him.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Long live the high and mighty King of Fesse.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
If thou bringest her then dost thou bring me life.
Say, will she come?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
She will my Lord, but yet conditionally
She may be free from violence.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Now by the mighty Prophet we adore,
She shall live Lady of her free desires,
It is love, not force, must quench our amorous fires.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: We will conduct her to your presence straight.

div2.stage: Enter Besse Bridges vail'd, Goodlack, Roughman, Forset, and Moores.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p:
We will have banquets, revels, and what not
To entertain this stranger.
A goodly presence! why is that beauty veiled?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Long live the King of Fesse.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
I am amazed,
This is no mortal creature I behold,
But some bright Angel that is dropped from heaven,
Sent by our prophet. Captain, let me thus
Embrace thee in my arms. Load him with gold
For this great favour.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Captain, touch it not.
Know King of Fesse my followers want no gold,
I only came to see thee for my pleasure,
And show thee, what these say thou never sawest,
A woman borne in England.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
That English earth may well be termed a heaven,
That breeds such divine beauties. Make me sure
That thou art mortal, by one friendly touch.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Keep off: for till thou swearest to my demands
I will have no commerce with Mullisheg,
But leave thee as I came.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Were it half my Kingdom,
That, beauteous English Virgin, thou shalt have.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Captain read.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
First, liberty for her and hers to leave the Land
at her pleasure.
Next, safe conduct to and from her ship at her own
discretion.
Thirdly, to be free from all violence, either by the King
or any of his people.
Fourthly, to allow her mariners fresh victuals aboard.
Firstly, to offer no further violence to her person, than
what he seeks by kingly usage, and free entreaty.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: To these I vow and seal.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
These being assured
Your courtship is free, and henceforth we secured.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Say Gentlemen of England, what is your fashion
And garb of entertainment?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Our first greeting
Begins still on the lips.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p:
Fair creature, shall I be immortalised
With that high favour?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
It is no immodest thing
You ask, nor shame, for Besse to kiss a King.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: This kiss hath all my vitals ectasied.

sp.speaker: Rou.
sp.p:
Captain this king is mightily in love. Well let her
Do as she list, I will make use of his bounty.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: We should be mad men else.

sp.speaker: Mullish.
sp.p: Grace me so much as take your seat by me.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: I will be so far commanded.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Sweet, your age?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Not fully yet seventeen.

sp.speaker: Mu.
sp.p:
But how your birth? how came you to this wealth,
To have such Gentlemen at your command?
And what your cause of travel?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Mighty Prince,
If you desire to see me beat my breast,
Pour forth a river of increasing tears,
Then you may urge me to that sad discourse.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Not for Mamorrahs wealth, nor all the gold
Coined in rich Barbary. Nay sweet arise,
And ask of me be it half this kingdom's treasure,
And thou art Lady of it.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
If I shall ask, it must be, you will not give.
Our country breeds no beggars, for our hearts
Are of more noble temper.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Sweet, your name?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
There is virtue in that name.
The Virgin Queen so famous through the world,
The mighty Empress of the maiden-isle,
Whose predecessors have overrun great France,
Whose powerful hand doth still support the Dutch,
And keeps the potent King of Spain in awe,
Is not she titled so?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: She is.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Hath she herself a face so fair as yours
When she appears for wonder.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Mighty Fesse,
You cast a blush upon my maiden cheek,
To pattern me with her. Why Englands Queen
She is the only Phoenix of her age,
The pride and glory of the Western Isles:
Had I a thousand tongues they all would tire
And fail me in her true description.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Grant me this,
Tomorrow we supply our Judgement-seat,
And sentence causes, sit with us in state,
And let your presence beautify our Throne.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: In that I am your servant.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p:
And we thine.
Set on in state, attendants, and full train:
But find to ask, we vow thou shalt obtain.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
It is not now as when Andrea lived,
Or rather Andrew our elder Journeyman: what, Drawers
become Courtiers? Now may I speak with the old ghost
in Ieronimo;
When this eternal substance of my soul
Did live imprisoned in this wanton flesh,
I was a Courtier in the Court of Fesse.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
O well done Clem. It is your Mistress pleasure
None come a shore that is not well habited.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Nay for mine own part, I hold myself as good
a Christian in these clothes, as the proudest Infidel of
them all.

sp.speaker: Alcade.
sp.p: Sir, by your leave, you are of the English train?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I am so thou great Monarch of the Mauritanians.

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p: Then it is the Kings command we give you all attendance

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Great Seignior of the Saracens I thank thee.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Will you walk in to banquet?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
I will make bold to march in towards your banquet,
and there comfort myself, and cast all caraways
down my throat, the best way I have to conserve myself in health: and for your countries sake which is called
Barbery, I will love all Barbers and Barberies the better:
And for you Moors, thus much I mean to say,
I will see if Moore I eat the Moore I may.

sp.speaker: 1. Merch.
sp.p: I pray sir are you of the English train?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Why what art thou my friend?

sp.speaker: 1 Mer.
sp.p:
Sir, a French merchant run into relapse,
And forfeit of the Law: here is for you sir
Forty good Barbery pieces to deliver
Your Lady this petition, who I hear
Can all things with the King.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Your gold doth bind me to you: you may see
what it is to be a sudden Courtier. I no sooner put my nose
into the Court, but my hand itches for a bribe already.
What is your business my friend?

sp.speaker: 2 Mer.
sp.p:
Some of my men for a little outrage done
Are sentenced to the Galleys.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: To the Gallows?

sp.speaker: 2 Mer.
sp.p:
No, to the Galleys: now could your Lady purchase
Their pardon from the King, here is twenty angels?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: What are you sir?

sp.speaker: 2 Merc.
sp.p: A Florentine Merchant.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Then you are, as they say, a Christian?

sp.speaker: 2 Mer.
sp.p: Heaven forbid else.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
I should not have the faith to take your gold else.
Attend on me, I will speak in your behalf.
Where be my Bashawes? usher us in state, Flourish.
And when we fit to banquet see you wait.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
This day the king ascends his royal throne,
The honest Merchant in whose ship I came,
Hath by a cunning quiddit in the Law
Both ship and goods made forfeit to the king,
To whom I will petition. But no more,
He is now upon his entrance.

div2.stage: Enter the King, Besse, Goodlacke, Roughman, Alcade, Ioffer, with all the other Traine.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Here seat thee Maid of England like a Queen,
The style we will give thee, wilt thou deign us love.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Bless me you holy Angels.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: What is it offends you Sweet?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: I am amazed, and know not what to think of it.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Captain, dost not see? Is not that Spencers ghost?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: I see, and like you I am ectasied.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
If mine eyes mistake not,
That should be Captain Goodlacke, and that Besse.
But O, I cannot be so happy.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: It is he, and I will salute him.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Captain stay,
You shall be swayed by me.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Him I well know, but how should she come hither

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: What is it that troubles you?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Most mighty king,
Spare me no longer time, but to bestow
My Captain on a message.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Thou shalt command my silence, and his ear.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Go wind about, and when you see least eyes
Are fixed on you, single him out and see
If we mistake not. If he be the man,
Give me some private note.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: This.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Enough. What said you highness?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Hark what I proffer thee, Continue here,
And grant me full fruition of thy love.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Thou shalt have all my Peers to honour thee
Next our great prophet.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
And when thou art weary of our Sun-burnt clime,
Thy Negro shall be ballast home with gold.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
I am eternized ever.
Now all you sad disasters dare your worst,
I neither care nor fear: my Spencer lives.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: You mind me not sweet Virgin.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
You talk of love.
My Lord, I will tell you more of that hereafter.
But now to your State business: bid him do thus
No more, and not be seen till then.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Enough: come sir, you must along with me.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Now stood a thousand deaths before my face,
I would not change my cheer, since Spencer is safe.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: By your leave my Masters: room for Generosity.

sp.speaker: 1 Merch.
sp.p: Pray sir remember me.

sp.speaker: 2 Merch.
sp.p: Good sir, my suit.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p:
I am perfect in both your parts without prompting,
Mistress, here are two christen friends of mine have forfeited
ships and men to the black a Morrian king. Now one
sweet word from your lips might get their release. I have
had a feeling of the business already.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p:
For dealing in commodities forbid
You are fined a thousand ducats.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Cast off the burden of your heavy doom,
A follower of my train petitions for him.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: One of thy train, sweet Besse?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: And no worse man than myself sir.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Well sirrah, for your Ladies sake,
His ship and goods shall be restored again.

sp.speaker: 1 Mer.
sp.p: Long live the King of Fesse.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Mayst thou never want sweet water to wash thy
black face in, most mighty Monarch of Morocco.
Mistress, another friend, I, and paid before hand.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Sirrah, your men for outrage and contempt
Are doomed unto the Galleys.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
A censure too severe for Christians.
Great King, I will pay their ransom.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p:
Thou my Besse?
Thy word shall be their ransom, they are discharged.
What grave old man is that?

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p:
A Christian Preacher, one that would convert
Your Moors, and turn them to a new belief.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Then he shall die, as we are king of Fesse.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
For these I only spake, for him I kneel,
If I have any grace with mighty Fesse.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p:
We can deny thee nothing beauteous maid,
A kiss shall be his pardon.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Thus I pay it.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Must your black face be smooching my Mistresses
white lips with a moorian. I would you had kissed her a -

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Ha, how is that sir?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I know what I say sir, I would he had kissed her a -

sp.speaker: Alcade.
sp.p: A-what?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: A thousand times to have done him a pleasure.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
That kiss was worth the ransom of a King.
What is he of that brave presence?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
A Gentleman of England, and my friend,
Do him some grace for my sake.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
For thy sake what would not I perform?
He shall have grace and honour. Ioffer, go
And see him gelded to attend on us,
He shall be our chief Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Not for ten worlds. Behold great king I stand
Betwixt him and all danger. Have I found thee?
Seize what I have, take both my ship and goods,
Leave naught that is mine unrifled: spare me him.
And have I found my Spencer!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Please your Majesty, I see all men are not capable
of honour, what he refuseth, may it please you to bestow
on me.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
With all my heart. Go bear him hence Alcade,
Into our Alkedavy, honour him,
And let him taste the razor.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: There is honour for me.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Come follow.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: No sir, I will go before you for mine honour.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
O show yourself renowned king the same
Fame blazons you: bestow this Maid on me,
It is such a gift as kingdoms cannot buy:
She is a president of all true love,
And shall be registered to after times,
That never shall pattern her.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Heard you the story of their constant love.
It would move in you compassion.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p:
Let not intemperate love sway you above pity,
That foreign nation that never heard your name,
May chronicle your virtues.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
You have wakened in me an heroic spirit:
Lust shall not conquer virtue. Till this hour
We graced thee for thy beauty English woman,
But now we wonder at thy constancy.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
O were you of our faith, I would swear great Mullisheg
To be a god on earth. And lives my Spencer?
In troth I thought thee dead.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
In hope of thee
I lived to gain both life and liberty.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
No more of your honour if you love me. Is this
your Moorish preferment to rob a man of his best jewels?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Hast thou seen our Alkedavy?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Davy do you call him? he may be called shavee
I am sure he hath tickled my currant commodity,
No more your cutting honour if you love me.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p:
All your strange fortunes we will hear discoursed
And after that your fair espousals grace,
If you can find a man of your belief
To do that grateful office.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
None more fit
Than this religious and grave Gentleman
Late rescued from deaths sentence.

sp.speaker: Preacher.
sp.p:
None more proud
To do you that poor service.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p:
Noble Englishman,
I cannot fasten bounty to my will,
Worthy thy merit, move some suite to us.

sp.speaker: Spencer.
sp.p:
To make you more renowned great king, and us
The more indebted, there is an Englishman
Hath forfeited his ship for goods uncustomed.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p:
Thy suite is granted ere it be half begged,
Dispose them at thy pleasure.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Mighty king
We are your Highness servants.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p:
Come beauteous Maid, we will see thee crowned a bride,
At all our pompous banquets these shall wait.
Thy followers and thy servants press with gold,
And not the meanest that to thy train belongs,
But shall approve our bounty. Lead in state,
And wheresoever thy fame shall be enrolled,
The world report thou art a Girl worth gold.
